snippet: Medicare has decided to pay physicians to discuss end-of-life care with patients. But it’s not clear that doctors are prepared for the task.
abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age column discusses decision by Medicare to authorize payments to doctors for end-of-life discussions with their patients, pointing to ebbing of outrage and fear that first surrounded issue when it was introduced as part of Affordable Care Act in 2009; many health-care providers, however, lack training in how to discuss sensitive subject with patients and to ensure their wishes are heeded.
lead_paragraph: Medicare has decided to pay physicians to discuss end-of-life care with patients. But it’s not clear that doctors are prepared for the task.

headline.main: A Quiet End to the ‘Death Panels’ Debate
